li.p: In this figure below, \triangle ABC has been rotated once around point D, and translated by vector \overrightarrow{u}. Do you think we can get from the left triangle to the right triangle in a single rigid motion?

figure.caption: \triangle PQR and it's rotation and translation

li.p: Perhaps you have come to the conclusion that it is a single rotation. How would one go about finding the rotation's center?

figure.caption: \triangle PQR and it's rotation and translation

hint.p: If A and A'' is a single rotation, that would mean that they lie on the same circle. What would that mean about the distance from the center of the circle to A and A''?

li.p: Because points on a circle are all the same distance from the center of the circle (definition of radius), then if point O is the center of the circle, then \overline{OA''} = \overline{OA''}.

figure.caption: \triangle PQR and it's rotation and translation

hint.p: If \overline{OA} = \overline{OA''}, then O lies on the perpendicular bisector of AA''.
